references: An attack succeeds if the trained model can misclassify the triggered examples to the target label. To increase the attack success rate, during the attacker’s training, we add a special pixel pattern to 20 images in a batch of 64 [4], and change their labels to 0 for MNIST and bird for CIFAR10. Especially for DBA, the global trigger pattern is divided into multiple local triggers and each local trigger is added by one of the colluding adversaries. At the inference time, the inputs are added with the same pixel pattern to trigger the backdoor. We adjust the configuration of each attack method to change the attack strength. The configurable factors are: (i) Attack frequency (Fmsubscript𝐹𝑚F_{m}): For DPA and LIE, the attack can be made more effective by repeating it at every iteration of FL. For MPA and DBA, multiple-shot (MS) and single-shot (SS) attacks are possible [16]; (ii) Scaling factor (γ𝛾\gamma): For single-shot MPA and DBA, γ𝛾\gamma is set to 10. This is determined by γ=N/η𝛾𝑁𝜂\gamma=N/\eta [4] to guarantee that the backdoor survives averaging when the global model is replaced by the backdoored model222N𝑁N represents the total number of clients, and η𝜂\eta denotes global learning rate which controls the fraction of joint models that are updated every round. Our setting is based on n=10𝑛10n=10 and η=1𝜂1\eta=1.. For multiple-shot MPA, γ𝛾\gamma is set to 5, which guarantees the attack effectiveness and utility of the global model. We found out experimentally that when γ𝛾\gamma is increased to 10, the main task accuracy of the aggregated model will be severely degraded. For multiple-shot DBA, we set γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 to support the every-round attack of the original paper; (iii) Number of adversaries at each attacking iteration (Nmsubscript𝑁𝑚N_{m}): For DPA and LIE, we evaluate Nm=5subscript𝑁𝑚5N_{m}=5 and Nm=9subscript𝑁𝑚9N_{m}=9 out of 10 clients. For DBA, Nmsubscript𝑁𝑚N_{m} is set to 4 and 6 out of 10 clients as in [16]. For MPA, if multiple adversaries exist in a given round, their respective scaled-up updates are divided evenly to keep the scaling valid. As the attack strength is independent of Nmsubscript𝑁𝑚N_{m}, Nmsubscript𝑁𝑚N_{m} is set to 1. In general, state-of-the-art attacks [19, 17] and defense [50] assume up to 50% of FL clients can be compromised. Hence, we test our scheme with up to at least this bound. The extreme attack with only one benign client is also tested. The abbreviations of the canonical attacks and their characteristics are listed in Table I.

The MA and ASR of each FL method with increasing iterations for MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets are shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, respectively. Each subfigure corresponds to one of the attacks listed in Table I. Different line colors represent different defense methods, as indicated by the legend of Fig. 2(a).
